From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia


2023 film by Bess Wohl


Baby RubyTheatrical release posterDirected byBess WohlWritten byBess WohlProduced by

CinematographyJuan Pablo RamírezEdited byJin LeeMusic byErik FriedlanderProductioncompanies

FilmNation Entertainment
Distributed byMagnet ReleasingRelease dates
September 9, 2022 (2022-09-09) (TIFF)
February 3, 2023 (2023-02-03) (United States)
Running time90 minutes[1]CountryUnited StatesLanguageEnglishBox office$16,991[2][3]
Baby Ruby is a 2022 American psychological horror-thriller film[4] written and directed by Bess Wohl, in her directorial debut. It stars Noémie Merlant, Kit Harington, and Meredith Hagner.
The film had its world premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival on September 9, 2022. It was released on February 3, 2023, by Magnet Releasing.


Plot[edit]
Jo (Noémie Merlant) is a lifestyle influencer. Her relationship with Spencer (Kit Harington) strengthens as they wait for the couple's first baby, named Ruby. After the birth of Ruby, Jo's successful world begins to fall apart as she suffers postpartum depression. Jo begins to behave aggressively and doubtfully, although she receives support from Shelly (Meredith Hagner), a neighbor who claims to be a mother even though she refuses to show her supposed baby to others. Jo becomes suspicious of the intentions of Shelly and everyone around her as she tries to protect her baby, who is also seen by Jo as someone hostile.[5]

Cast[edit]
Noémie Merlant as Jo
Kit Harington as Spencer
Meredith Hagner as Shelly
Reed Birney as Dr. Rosenbaum
Jayne Atkinson as Doris
Release[edit]
The film had its world premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival on September 9, 2022.[6] Shortly after, Magnet Releasing acquired US distribution rights to the film.[7] It was released on February 3, 2023.[8]

Reception[edit]
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 67% of 45 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 6.3/10. The website's consensus reads: "A flawed but finely cut gem, Baby Ruby puts the horror of new parenthood under a frighteningly effective magnifying glass."[9] Metacritic, which uses a weighted average, assigned the film a score of 57 out of 100, based on 10 critics, indicating "mixed or average" reviews.[10]
In a review for San Francisco Chronicle, Bob Strauss wrote: "Playwright Bess Wohl’s feature-directing debut is a sly, mutant meld of horror thriller, feminist satire and subjective, postpartum paranoia study. It’s serious about how the demands of baby care can overwhelm, and skeptical of societal pressures on women to not just accept but love motherhood’s burdens."[11]
